The stability of Al2O3-based catalysts used to hydrolyze COS from blast furnace gas is significantly challenging in the iron and steel industry. Targeting this challenge, the enhanced catalytic activity and stability are demonstrated, using Sm and K dual-metal co-modified 3–4 mm Al2O3 pellets commonly used in industry. In a simulated blast furnace gas atmosphere, the catalyst impregnated with K followed by Sm and calcined twice(Sm→K/Al2O3)show the highest hydrolysis efficiency, reaching 98 % during 10 h. XPS combined with CO2-TPD and EPR shows that there is a strong electron transfer between Sm and K, which significantly increases the quantity of weak basic sites and oxygen vacancies. With the introduction of Sm, more stable lattice oxygen is generated, which further prevents the sulfation of K and maintains good stability. In addition, the COS hydrolysis reaction mechanism of Sm→K/Al2O3 has been proposed by in-situ DRIFTS. This work provides convenience for further research on catalysts promoting COS hydrolysis and their industrial applications. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords COS hydrolysis Electron transfer Alkali and rare earth metals Alkaline sites and oxygen vacancies Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As a secondary energy source, blast furnace gas (BFG) is widely utilized in hot blast furnaces and gas power generation in self-owned power plants [1,2]. Sulfide in BFG is mainly a mixture of COS (50∼200 mg/m3) and H2S (10∼50mg/m3), which will pollute the environment, corrode pipeline equipment, and cause catalyst sulfur poisoning [3]. Due to the bond dissociation energies of C = O and C = S in COS molecules are 728 and 536 kJ/mol respectively, COS is difficult to dissociate and remove [4]. Among the many methods of removal [5–8], because the hydrolysis conversion (COS+H2OH2S+CO2) has the advantages of mild conditions, high conversion rate and the blast furnace gas contains 7 %−10 % H2O, it is the best method at present [9,10]. The catalyst that is both efficient and stable is the key to COS hydrolysis. COS hydrolysis is considered to be a alkali catalyzed reaction [11]. Al2O3-based alkali solid catalysts have been diffusely used in the industrial field because the conversion rate of pure Al2O3 reached about 50 % [12,13]. The hydrolysis performance of Al2O3 could be enhanced by adding active components [4,14–19]. Thomas et al. [15] suggested that alkali metal K is more beneficial to improve the performance by analyzing the effect of alkali metal and alkaline earth metal on the hydrolysis efficiency of the aluminum-based catalyst COS. Gu et al. [11] modified the aluminum-based catalyst with KOH and improved the hydrolysis performance of the catalyst by increasing the base site of the catalyst. Nevertheless, due to oxidation of the generated H2S to sulfate deposition, resulting in reduced activity [19,20]. Due to the unique 4f electronic structure of rare earth elements and the presence of vacant 5d orbitals, it can regulate the surface electrons of the catalyst and the catalytic active site [21–23]. Wang et al. [24] applied Sm to NOx(SCR) and proposed that Sm can increase oxygen vacancy and electron transfer and slow down the vulcanization process of the catalyst. Furthermore, rare earth metals can provide an additional protective layer and sulfur adsorbed at the alkaline sites of alumina can be transferred to rare earth metals, slowing catalyst deactivation caused by catalyst poisoning [12,25]. In O2 atmosphere, Sm can effectively resist the sulfate poisoning caused by the catalyst and it can increase the active site of the catalyst, which is more conducive to COS adsorption [17,26,27]. In this study, K/Sm/Al2O3 sphere samples with different impregnation sequence and calcination time were prepared for COS hydrolysis. Fixed-bed gas chromatography was used to investigate COS hydrolysis conversion and it was concluded that Sm→K/Al2O3 exhibited the best hydrolysis performance. Table 1 summarizes the aluminum-based catalysts reported to date for COS hydrolysis. The comparison indicates that Sm→K/Al₂O₃ exhibits higher stability, maintaining a conversion rate above 91 % still after 100 h of testing. Combined with characterization, the physicochemical properties of the catalyst were analyzed. Enhanced electron transfer after Sm doping increased the basic sites and oxygen vacancies of the catalyst, which improved the hydrolysis performance of the catalyst. Analysis of the Sm→K/Al₂O₃ reaction mechanism by in-situ DRIFTS. Provides theoretical support for the industrial application of efficient catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation In this work, industrial alumina Al2O3 sphere was used as catalyst carrier. Al2O3 catalysts supported by K and Sm were prepared by different impregnation sequences and calcined times. K/Al2O3: The KOH with a mass fraction of 10 % was dissolved in 50 ml deionized water, and the Al2O3 ball was added to the solution for ultrasonic impregnation for 2 h, drying at 110℃ for 6 h, and calcining at 350℃ for 3 h. Sm/Al2O3: Sm(NO3)3·6H2O with a mass fraction of 3 % was dissolved in 50 ml deionized water. Ultrasonic impregnation of Al2O3 ball for 2 h, drying at 110℃ for 6 h, calcination at 350℃ for 3 h. Sm→K/Al2O3: KOH with A mass fraction of 10 % was dissolved in 50 ml deionized water to prepare solution A, which was added to Al2O3 pellets, impregnated by ultrasonic impregnating for 2 h, dry at 110℃ for 6 h, and calcined at 350℃ for 3 h. Solution B was prepared by dissolving Sm(NO3)3·6H2O with mass fraction of 3 % in deionized water. The substrate was added to solution B, impregnated by ultrasonic impregnating for 2 h, dry at 110℃ for 6 h, and calcined at 350℃ for 3 h to obtain the catalyst. K→Sm/Al2O3: Sm(NO3)3·6H2O with A mass fraction of 3 % was dissolved in 50 ml deionized water as solution A, and Al2O3 pellets were added to solution A. Ultrasonic impregnation for 2 h, drying at 110℃ for 6 h, calcination at 350℃ for 3 h. Solution B was prepared by dissolving 10 % KOH in 50 ml deionized water. The calcined Sm/Al2O3 pellets were added to solution B, impregnated by ultrasonic for 2 h, dried at 110℃ for 6 h, and calcined at 350℃ for 3 h. Sm-K/Al2O3: Solution A was prepared by dissolving 10 % KOH in 50 ml deionized water, adding Al2O3 pellets into solution A, ultrasonic impregnating for 2 h, dry at 110℃ for 6 h. Solution B was prepared by dissolving 3 % Sm(NO3)3·6H2O in deionized water. The substrate was added to solution B, impregnated by ultrasonic impregnating for 2 h, dry at 110℃ for 6 h, and calcined at 350℃ for 3 h to obtain the catalyst. K-Sm/Al2O3: Sm(NO3)3·6H2O with A mass fraction of 3 % was dissolved in 50 ml deionized water and prepared into solution A. Al2O3 pellets were added into solution A for 2 h of ultrasonic impregnation and 6 h of drying at 110℃. Solution B was prepared by dissolving 10 % KOH in 50 ml deionized water. The dried Sm/Al2O3 pellets were added to solution B, impregnated by ultrasonic for 2 h, dried at 110℃ for 6 h, and calcined at 350℃ for 3 h. 2.2 Catalyst activity evaluation In a fixed bed reactor, catalyst was loaded into a quartz tube with an inner diameter of 15 mm. COS hydrolysis activity was investigated using a tube furnace to control the hydrolysis temperature and 12 g of spherical catalyst at atmospheric pressure. According to the BFG, the simulated flue gas is composed of COS (100 ppm), H2S (100 ppm), CO2 (20 %), CO (20 %), H2 (1 %), O2 (1 %), and N2 equilibria at atmospheric pressure. At room temperature and 1atm, the total flow rate is set to 600 ml/min and the airspeed is 2000h−1. Analysis of COS concentration by gas chromatography (Fig. 1 ). The COS removal rate is calculated by the following formula : COS Conversion = C O S i n − C O S o u t C O S i n × 100 COSin is the import concentration and COSout is the export concentration. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity As shown in Fig. 2 a, within 100 °C and 10 h, the conversion rates of Al2O3 and K/Al2O3 are 59 % and 90 %, respectively. The conversions of Sm→K/Al2O3, Sm-K/Al2O3, K→Sm/Al2O3, and K-Sm/Al2O3 prepared by different preparation methods were 98 %, 88 %, 83 %, and 77 %, respectively. Stability tests for the Sm→K/Al2O3 were conducted over a period of 100 h, and the conversion rate remained above 91 % (Fig. 2b). The high performance of the Sm→K/Al2O3 catalyst can be attributed to the enhanced synergistic effects between the metals. The catalyst after the reaction was heated to 500 °C in a nitrogen atmosphere, calcined for 180 min, and then impregnated with an alkaline solution for 2 h before being dried. After two regeneration cycles, the conversion rate remained at 95 % (Fig.S1). 3.2 Phase structure analysis The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 39.49°, 67.03°, and 85.01° correspond to the (222), (400), and (440) crystal faces of Al2O3, respectively. With different preparation methods, the diffraction peaks of the samples loaded with K and Sm did not shift significantly. XRD patterns did not observe the characteristic diffraction peaks of K and Sm, indicating that their particle sizes are very small and highly dispersed on the carrier. Interestingly, AlO(OH) (PDF-ICDD 21–1307) diffraction peaks appeared at 2θ = 14.50° and 28.30° when KOH was first impregnated. A certain amount of AlO(OH) was generated by the reaction of KOH with Al2O3 to provide a basic site for the reaction [31], in which the diffraction peaks were preserved after loading Sm (Fig. 3 ). In Fig.S3, the diffraction peaks of K2SO4 are observed in the catalyst after the reaction; however, the Sm→K/Al2O3 catalyst still shows the diffraction peak of AlO(OH). This indicates that the interaction between Sm and K produces additional basic sites, thereby enhancing both activity and stability. 3.3 Structural characterization The specific surface area, pore size and pore volume of various samples were measured using a nitrogen adsorption apparatus [32]. All samples exhibited typical Langmuir IV isothermal adsorption lines [11]. Through the pore size distribution curve, it is concluded that the most available pore size of the catalyst is 5∼8 nm, with a uniform mesoporous structure which is favorable for the adsorption and mass transfer of reactant molecules(Fig.S2) [30]. Compared with the Al₂O₃, when only 3 % Sm is added, the specific surface area and pore volume are significantly reduced because Sm particles are embedded in the pores. There was no significant change in the pore volume and pore size of the samples after loading with K and Sm, suggesting that this is not a major factor affecting the catalytic performance(Table S1). However, the average pore diameter of all catalysts is still much larger than the molecular kinetic diameters of COS (0.34 nm) and H2O (0.27 nm-0.32 nm), indicating that COS and H2O can enter the internal pores of the catalyst for hydrolysis reaction. whether the difference in performance are due to inconsistencies in sample elemental composition was tested by ICP. The results show that the samples obtained by different preparation methods have approximately the same K and Sm contents(Table S1). It suggested that the reason affecting the performance may be the different interactions between the metals. 3.4 Surface alkalinity investigation Catalyst surface alkalinity is crucial for the adsorption and hydrolysis of COS [33]. Characterization of the center of alkalinity distribution of samples was conducted using carbon dioxide programmed warming desorption methods(Fig. 4 ). Weakly basic sites (-OH groups) for peaks at 50–200 °C; moderately strongly basic sites (M-O groups) for 200–550 °C; strongly basic sites (O2- groups) above 550 °C [34]. Studies have shown that the weakly basic site is the main hydrolytically active site [35]. Perform Gaussian fitting on peaks of varying basicity intensities, obtain the peak areas, and subsequently calculate the percentage of basic sites [17]. Table 2 shows the peak areas of various alkaline centers. In comparison to Al2O3, Sm/Al2O3 exhibits a lower number of weak alkaline sites, which results in diminished performance. K/Al2O3 and Sm→K/Al2O3 increased by 29.4 % and 38 %, respectively, relative to the weakly basic sites of Al2O3. which is due to the weakly basic sites provided by AlO(OH), and the addition of Sm generates more weakly basic sites that to improve the hydrolysis efficiency. By comparing Sm→K/Al2O3 and K→Sm/Al2O3, Sm-K/Al2O3 and K-Sm/Al2O3, it can be found that Sm→K/Al2O3 and Sm-K/Al2O3 produce more weak alkaline points. We believe that AlO(OH), which is formed by impregnating KOH first, provides the weak alkaline site required for the reaction, and two calcinations further improves the alkaline distribution and increases the abundance of base sites. Hence, the weakly basic sites and abundant base sites can enhance the adsorption and activation of COS, thus improving the hydrolysis performance of COS. 3.5 Surface element composition analysis The elemental composition and valence states of the catalyst were studied using XPS, analyzing the surface chemical environment of the samples. Oxygen species play a key role in the hydrolysis reaction of COS [36]. As shown in Fig. 5 , Oα (532–532.6 eV) is attributed to adsorbed H2O molecules and -OH; Oβ (531.1–531.5 eV) is attributed to the adsorption state of oxygen-containing O2−, O2 or O−; Oγ (530–530.4 eV) is attributed to lattice oxygen [37]. Hydroxy-oxygen plays a key role in the hydrolysis reaction [38]. Hydroxyl oxygen primarily originates from -OH groups on the catalyst surface and from -OH groups dissociated from adsorbed water molecules, which directly participate in the reaction to enhance hydrolysis performance [39]. By integrating the peak areas, the content of different alkaline centers can be determined. Compared with Al2O3, the hydroxyl oxygen content of K/Al2O3 and Sm→K/Al2O3 increased by 8.7 % and 15.5 %, respectively, indicating that the addition of Sm enhanced the surface alkalinity of the catalyst to a point. Obtained by different preparation methods, Sm→K/Al2O3 has the highest hydroxyl‑oxygen ratio, which is consistent with the hydrolysis properties and CO2-TPD test results. AlO(OH) formed by KOH is the main source of hydroxyl oxygen in Sm→K/Al2O3. The intensity of the Oβ peak for Sm→K/Al2O3 is higher than that of Al2O3 (Table 2), resulting in more K or Sm atoms being exposed, leading to incomplete bonding, which makes the oxygen atoms in Al2O3 more prone to breaking and forming oxygen vacancies [40]. Due to the change in the binding energy of K and Sm, it indicates that their binding state with the surface oxygen atoms of Al₂O₃ has changed (Fig.S3). The shift of the Sm 3d peak for Sm→K/Al₂O₃ towards lower binding energy is the most significant, suggesting that the binding of Sm³+ with Al₂O₃ is weaker, which promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies. Peak splitting of K/Al2O3 and O 1 s of Sm→K/Al2O3 after reaction is shown in Fig. 7a, the results of peak area integration are shown in Table S2. After the reaction, the Oβ decreased and Oγ increased. Due to the addition of Sm in Sm→K/Al2O3, more adsorbed oxygen is converted into lattice oxygen, thus reducing the formation of sulfide, which contributes to the efficiency of hydrolysis. By analyzing the XPS spectra of K and Sm of Sm→K/Al2O3 catalysts(Fig. 6(a-b)). Sm 3d5/2 and Sm 3d3/2 were observed at around 1083 eV and 1110 eV, respectively, indicating that Sm had been doped into Al2O3 [41]. K 2p1/2 and K 2p3/2 were observed at around 293 eV and 296 eV, which may be caused by K+matter [42]. In K/Al2O3, K 2p3/2 and K 2p1/2 are 295.24 eV and 292.41 eV, respectively. For Sm→K/Al2O3, K2p3/2 and K2p1/2 are 295.58 eV and 292.87 eV respectively. After the addition of Sm, the K substance of Sm→K/Al2O3 catalyst moves to the direction of higher binding energy. Sm 3d3/2 values of Sm/Al2O3 and Sm→K/Al2O3 are 1110.35 eV and 1110.1 eV, and Sm 3d5/2 values are 1083.3 eV and 1083 eV, respectively. Compared to Sm/Al2O3, the Sm 3d peak of Sm→K/Al2O3 shifts to a lower binding energy direction. The addition of Sm makes it easier for K to lose electrons, while Sm gains electrons and increases electron cloud density, thereby enhancing its ability as a Lewis base and strengthening the weak basic sites of the catalyst [43,44]. This is consistent with the results of O 1 s and CO2-TPD. K 2p and Sm 3d peaks in catalysts prepared by different methods are compared in Fig.S4. When Sm was first impregnated, due to the interaction between Sm and O, the binding energy of K changed little, and Sm occupied the active site, which could not provide the weak alkaline point required for the reaction [23]. When KOH is impregnated first, the binding energy of K changes significantly, making it easier to lose electrons and providing more weakly basic sites for the reaction, confirming the impact of the impregnation order on hydrolysis efficiency. According to the Sm 3d5/2XPS spectral results (Fig. 6 c), two different valence states of Sm were observed. The combined capacity of Sm3+ and Sm2+ is 1083.6 eV and 1081.7 eV [45]. After the reaction, the ratio of Sm3+:Sm2+ changed from 61.2:38.8 to 45.4:54.6, which is due to the electron transfer between Sm3+ and Sm2+, the amount of Sm3+ decreased, and the content of Sm2+ increased. These results indicate that the high state of samarium can promote the hydrolysis of COS on the catalyst. To further investigate the reasons for the reduced activity, SEM analysis was conducted on the catalysts after the reaction. The results showed that all catalysts had sulfur deposition. Mapping indicated that in the Sm→K/Al2O3 catalyst, the distribution of K was more uniform, and the distribution of S was less and more uniform (Fig.S5). We analyzed the XPS spectra of S 2p in Fig. 7 b Because of the peaks at 168.3 eV for SO₄²⁻ and 162.8 eV for S [46]. The peak of SO4 2− was found in used-K/Al2O3, and the peak of elemental S was also found in used-sm→K/Al2O3. Sulfur poisoning on the catalyst surface is mainly due to the deposition of the generated H₂S first oxidized to S and then further oxidized to sulfate [47], it shows that the loading of Sm inhibits the oxidation of S. Through IC detection of the sulfur species content in the catalyst after the reaction (Fig.S6), the sulfur-containing substances in the Sm→K/Al2O3 catalyst are higher than those in K/Al2O3, indicating that the addition of Sm inhibits the formation of sulfate. 3.6 Oxygen vacancy analysis The concentration of oxygen vacancy was measured by EPR. As shown in Fig. 8 a, at g = 2.003, the catalyst shows an EPR peak, the intensity of which represents the concentration of the oxygen vacancy [48]. Peaks are higher, the more oxygen vacancies are present. Different catalysts are detected with the presence of oxygen vacancies, with Sm→K/Al2O3 oxygen vacancy signals being the strongest. Due to the doping of K into the Al2O3 lattice to form K⁺, it is necessary to compensate with positively charged oxygen vacancies to maintain electrical neutrality. The reduction of Sm (Sm³⁺ → Sm²⁺) exacerbates the charge imbalance, requiring more oxygen vacancies for compensation [49]. Therefore, the interaction between K and Sm generates more oxygen vacancies, which is consistent with the XPS results. Compared to Sm-K/Al2O3, Sm→K/Al2O3 exhibits a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies, which is due to the secondary calcination promoting the diffusion and migration of oxygen vacancies from the surface of the Al2O3 lattice to the interior, thereby increasing the concentration of oxygen vacancies [50]. The presence of oxygen vacancies facilitates the adsorption and activation of water molecules, leading to their dissociation and the formation of -OH, thereby improving the hydrolysis efficiency of COS. To further analyze oxygen species, O2-TPD experiments were conducted(Fig. 8). Oα is adsorbed oxygen at 100–300℃, attributed to the desorption peak of O2 molecules. Oβ is adsorbed oxygen at 300–600℃, due to O2 − desorption peak and Oγ is lattice oxygen above 600℃, due to O2− desorption peak [30,51]. The analysis temperature of the γoxygen species in the Sm→K/Al2O3 catalyst is lower than that of the K/Al2O3 catalyst (8c). The temperature obtained from different preparation methods for Sm→K/Al2O3 is significantly lower than that of the other three K/Sm/Al2O3 catalysts (8b), indicating that the lattice oxygen in Sm→K/Al2O3 has good mobility, which enhances the migration rate of the oxygen species. Additionally, the proportion distribution of the oxygen species was obtained by integrating the peak areas (Fig. S7). At 300 ∼ 600℃, the peak area of the Sm→K/Al2O3 catalyst (77.7 %) is greater than that of the other catalysts. Combined with EPR, it is found that there are more oxygen vacancies on the surface of Sm→K/Al2O3, which can adsorb and activate water molecules to dissociate and generate -OH, thereby improving the hydrolysis conversion rate. 3.7 Reaction mechanism revelation Analysis of the adsorption behavior of COS on Sm→K/Al2O3 was carried out by in-situ DRIFTS. N2 was pretreated at 300℃ for 1 h, and then COS was absorbed at 50℃ for 30 min and spectra were collected (Fig.S8). The adsorption peaks of COS are found at 2070 cm−1 and 2050 cm−1 [30]. The dominant band was in the 900 cm−1 ∼ 1700 cm−1, the band at 1665 cm−1 belonged to the HCO3 − species, and the adsorption peak of HSCO2 − was detected at 1500 cm−1 and 1270 cm−1 [10]. HSCO2 − is the main intermediate of the COS hydrolysis reaction. COS is adsorbed on Sm→K/Al2O3, and reacts with the -OH to form HSCO2 −, and then further reacts to produce CO2 and H2S. In order to analyze the hydrolysis mechanism of COS, COS+H2O was introduced at 100℃ and peaks of different reaction times were recorded. Pretreatment with N2 at 300℃ for 30 min prior to the test to remove the influence of impurities and interstitial water between catalyst particles. In Fig. 9 a, the vibrations at 980 cm−1 and 1368 cm−1 correspond to HSO3- bisulfate and SO4 2− sulfate [10,52]. Bands at 1418 cm−1 and 1635 cm−1 can be attributed to bending vibrations of bicarbonate (HCO3 −) [10]. At 1270 cm−1 and 1500 cm−1 can be attributed to stretching vibrations of hydrogen thiocarbonate (HSCO2 −). There were almost no significant HSCO2 −related peaks within 5 min after the reaction began, indicating that HSCO2 −related peaks did not appear in large numbers at the beginning of the reaction. However, after 10–20 min of reaction, HSCO2 −correlation peak appeared, indicating that HSCO2 −correlation was produced during COS hydrolysis. Little or no CO2 related peaks were evident within 5 min after the reaction, indicating that CO2 was not produced in large quantities at the start of the reaction. Nevertheless, CO2 related peaks appeared after 10 ∼ 20 min of reaction. These results indicate that HCO3 − and HSCO2 − are the main intermediates. Each peak strength increases after the passage of H2O, indicating that the participation of H2O promotes the adsorption and activation of COS. With the increase of reaction time, the adsorption peaks of the surface intermediate HSCO2 − gradually accumulated, while the adsorption peaks of HCO3 − may originate from the further reaction of surface -OH with HSCO2 −. Because the actual flue gas usually contains a small amount of O2 in it, the spectrum collected over time after COS+H2O+O2 is injected is shown in Fig. 9b After O2 passage, the intensity of each adsorption peak increased slightly. It is worth noting that at 1665cm−1, the adsorption peak strength of bicarbonate (HCO3 −) is significantly enhanced, indicating that indicating that O2 can promote COS hydrolysis. Based on in-situ DRIFTS,the possible COS hydrolysis reaction mechanism of the Sm→K/Al2O3 catalyst is proposed, as shown in Fig. 10 . COS firstly adsorbs on the catalyst surface and generates HSCO2 −with -OH on the catalyst surface, while H2O adsorbs on the oxygen vacancies to generate -OH, which generates CO2 and H2S with HSCO2 −. Both the K and Sm modified catalysts have more weak base sites, resulting in more reaction intermediates (HCO3 − and HSCO2 −). Our results showed that the adsorption capacity of Sm→K/Al2O3 on COS was significantly enhanced, and more active intermediates were generated to enhance the hydrolysis performance. 4 Conclusion In summary, by preparing Sm/K/Al2O3 catalyst, we obtained that the COS removal rate of Sm→K/Al2O3 catalyst remained above 98 % within 10 h. Through XPS and CO2-TPD analysis, the electronic interaction between K and Sm enhances electron transfer, thereby increasing the basic sites and oxygen vacancies of the catalyst. High-valent Sm promoted the hydrolysis of COS, as well as Sm doping prevented the further oxidation of H2S into sulfate thereby improving the stability of the Sm→K/Al2O3. Combined with in-situ DRIFTS, the modified catalysts generated more active intermediates (HCO3 − and HSCO2 −) with enhanced adsorption and activation of COS. This work develops Sm→K/Al2O3 which is an important contribution to BFG desulfurization technology and is conducive to practical industrial applications. coredata.dc:description: The stability of Al2O3-based catalysts used to hydrolyze COS from blast furnace gas is significantly challenging in the iron and steel industry. Targeting this challenge, the enhanced catalytic activity and stability are demonstrated, using Sm and K dual-metal co-modified 3–4 mm Al2O3 pellets commonly used in industry. In a simulated blast furnace gas atmosphere, the catalyst impregnated with K followed by Sm and calcined twice(Sm→K/Al2O3)show the highest hydrolysis efficiency, reaching 98 % during 10 h. XPS combined with CO2-TPD and EPR shows that there is a strong electron transfer between Sm and K, which significantly increases the quantity of weak basic sites and oxygen vacancies. With the introduction of Sm, more stable lattice oxygen is generated, which further prevents the sulfation of K and maintains good stability. In addition, the COS hydrolysis reaction mechanism of Sm→K/Al2O3 has been proposed by in-situ DRIFTS. This work provides convenience for further research on catalysts promoting COS hydrolysis and their industrial applications.
